Award.AwardTitle: Enabling Access to Priority Taxa for Biodiversity Studies in the Manter Laboratory of Parasitology
Award.AbstractNarration: A grant has been awarded to the University of Nebraska under the direction of Dr. Scott L. Gardner to expand access to the Harold W. Manter Laboratory of Parasitology collections. The collections include specimens of parasites of mammals from Brazil and Mexico, nematode parasites from forest insects (Coleoptera) that include many that were new to science at the time of collection. The specimens will be identified, repaired, and digitally photographed for incorporation into an online database of parasites at the university. This web-accessible database will be valuable to researchers and the public. Undergraduates and graduate students will be trained in parasite collection management and work on the database. At-risk middle school girls will be part of a summer science camp at the university during each year of the three year project.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
We expanded user access to previously unavailable collections housed in the HWML, including: 1) the parasites in the cryogenic facilities of the new Parasite Genomic Research Facility, 2) the ectoparasite collections from mammals obtained in Brazil and Mexico, and 3) the Calvin L. Massey collection of nematode parasites of forest Coleoptera, which contains several hundred type specimens. The work done aligns with the NSF BRC program goal to “conserve specimens from bioinventories and to enable identification of species.”  Specimens from each of these collections were identified, verified, repaired, all type specimens in the Massey Collection were digitally photographed, and re-housed and all salient data were added to PARASITE, the HWML’s searchable, Web-accessible database. 

In addition to conservation we taught three courses to underprivileged kids in the lincoln public schools. The courses were taught in the NU State Museum and were extremely successful and constituted a large part of our outreach and education for the Manter Laboratory for the three years of grant funding.

The project preserved, cataloged, and made accessible critical component of the earth’s biomass. Animals worldwide universally co-exist with parasites. Too often these ecto- and endosymbionts are discarded with no regard to the critical nature of the necessary relationship a host has with its parasites.  

Our project has enabled researchers working on bark beetles and their symbionts to utilize the data housed in the Massey Collection of the HWML Parasite collection. This is an important contribution to the development of forest resource management and continues to enable vibrant research on biodiversity. 

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2013
Modified by: Scott L Gardner
